Title.evidence: This study evaluated the feasibility of immediate urinary catheter removal after radical gastrectomy.

Trial_Design.evidence: This was a non-inferiority randomized clinical trial performed at a university-affiliated hospital in China.

Participants.evidence: Patients undergoing radical gastrectomy were randomized in a 1 : 1 ratio to either immediate removal (IR) or early removal (ER) of the urinary catheter.

Intervention.evidence: Patients undergoing radical gastrectomy were randomized in a 1 : 1 ratio to either immediate removal (IR) or early removal (ER) of the urinary catheter.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated the feasibility of immediate urinary catheter removal after radical gastrectomy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome measure was postoperative urinary retention with a non-inferiority margin of 10% to compare IR with ER.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The randomization sequence was computer generated; the investigators and patients were not blinded to group allocation.

Blinding.evidence: The investigators and patients were not blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Initially, 248 patients were assessed for eligibility for this study.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Data were analysed for 92 patients in the IR group and 89 patients in the ER group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The incidence of postoperative urinary retention was 4.4% and 3.4% in the IR and ER groups, respectively ( P = 0.733; 1.0% difference, 95% confidence interval âˆ’4.6 to 6.6%).
